title.narrative: Chad Digitalization of Revenue Administrations and COVID-19 Response Project

description.narrative: The development objectives of Domestic Resource Mobilization and Management Project for Chad is to improve performance, processes, and transparency in key government entities for revenue mobilization. This project has three components. 1) The first component, Results-based Financing to Support Change Management in Customs and Tax administrations, has the flowing subcomponents: (i) Support the utilization of a unified taxpayers registry for enterprises; (ii) Support the gradual adoption of electronic filing by large taxpayers; (iii) Support the roll out of mandatory tax payment by large taxpayers through the banking system; (iv) Support the gradual adoption of pay-by-phone by Small Taxpayers; and(v) Reduction in the number of physical custom inspections of imported merchandise; (vi) Reduction in the release time for imported merchandise. 2) The second component, Technical Assistance to Strengthen Revenue Agencies, aims to provide specialized TA, including technical experts for each area of intervention, to improve transparency, and increase accountability of the tax and customs administrations, petroleum, and telecom for revenue mobilization and management. It has the following subcomponents: (i) Improve Tax Administration and Policy; (ii) Improve Customs Administration; (iii) Increasing Transparency and Accountability of the Recipient's Revenue Agencies; (iv) Address Fiscal Challenges and Improve the Oversight of the ICT Sector; and (v) Improve the Management and Control of Revenue Generation in the Petroleum. 3) The third component, Project Management and Coordination, aims to support the ST-PAMFIP—a dedicated Project Implementation Unit embedded in the MoFB—to undertake project management, in accordance with the World Bank's fiduciary and other guidelines, including incremental operating costs, equipment, training on fiduciary and project management issues, project

condition.narrative: The Recipient shall: (a) no later than three (3) months after the Effective Date: (i) have acquired and installed a computerizedaccounting software capable of correctly recording and automatically generating financial statements (interim and annual); (ii)have hired an external auditor; and (iii) has hired an Independent Verification Agent for PBCs.

title.narrative: Average time for imported goods to clear customs
Number of tax offices in N'Djamena in which the New Tax Administration System has been rolled out
Number of customs offices in which ASYCUDA World has been rolled out
SHT's ability to produce financial reports from an integrated accounting and management information system (IAMIS)

target.value: Audited financial statements of year (t-1) are published

title.narrative: Establishment of unique identification number for enterprises for all administrations

baseline.value: Multiple taxpayers identification number are used across the administration

target.value: All administrations use the same identification number for taxpayers

actual.value: Multiple taxpayers identification numbers are still used across the administration. The scope of TA to provide to the taxadministration to meet the targets has been redefined.

title.narrative: PBC#6. Share of large enterprises paying taxes through the banking system.

baseline.value: 20 percent of large taxpayers use the banking syst

target.value: At least 70 percent of large taxpayers pay through the banking system.

actual.value: At least 70 percent of large taxpayers pay through the banking system.

title.narrative: PBC#4: Share of small entities paying Presumptive Income Tax for Small Entities (Impôt general libEratoire) by mobile payment.

baseline.value: 0 percent of small taxpayers use pay-by-phone

target.value: At least 20 percent of small taxpayers pay by mobile payment.

actual.value: The GoC is on track to meet the June 30, 2021 target. A draft contract with telephone operators for the implementation of mobilepayments has already been prepared by the DGSI and submitted to the review of the Minister of Finance. The review is pending.

title.narrative: PBC#5: Share of imported merchandise subject to physical inspections.

baseline.value: 100 percent of imported merchandise is subject to physical inspections.

target.value: No more than 65 percent of imported merchandise is subject to physical inspections.

actual.value: Risk-based inspections are implemented but not yet mandatory. The GoC is on track to meet the June 30, 2021 target.

title.narrative: Collection of tax and customs revenue measured as a percentage of non-oil GDP (excluding property tax and tax revenue from the oil sector)
Electronic filing of tax returns by large taxpayers
PBC#2: Share of food, necessity items and sanitary products imported to fight the COVID-19 pandemic, as identified in Circular 04/PR/MFB/2020, cleared through customs in less than 72 hours.
PBC#3: Share of tax returns processed in less than eight days.
PBC#1: Adapt the functioning of the tax and customs administration to manage the COVID-19 crisis in a transparent manner.

baseline.value: COVID-19 outbreak is declared a pandemic by WHO. There are no measures issued yet.

target.value: DLR#1.2: Four (4) quarterly economic notes issued by the tax and customs administration to the Minister of Finance detailing thefiscal cost of tax measures introduced during the COVID-19 crisis; and four (4) communications to the public (radio and televisionspots, publications in newspapers) and at least two (2) letters of information to the public on the economic and fiscal impact ofCOVID-19 measures.

actual.value: The Minister of Finance has issued circular 04/PR/MFB/2020 dated April 23, 2020 adopting social and economic measures to fightagainst COVID-19. These measures include fiscal and administrative measures to ensure the business continuity of the tax andcustoms administration.
